Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Kitchen \Kitch"en\ (k[i^]ch"[e^]n), n. [OE. kichen, kichene, kuchene, AS. cycene, L. coquina, equiv. to culina a kitchen, fr. coquinus pertaining to cooking, fr. coquere to cook. See {Cook} to prepare food, and cf. {Cuisine}.] 1. A room equipped for cooking food; the room of a house, restaurant, or other building appropriated to cookery. [1913 Webster]
Cool was his kitchen, though his brains were hot. --Dryden. [1913 Webster]
A fat kitchen makes a lean will. --Franklin. [1913 Webster]
2. A utensil for roasting meat; as, a tin kitchen. [1913 Webster]
3. The staff that works in a kitchen. [PJC]
{Kitchen garden}. See under {Garden}.
{Kitchen lee}, dirty soapsuds. [Obs.] ``A brazen tub of kitchen lee.'' --Ford.
{Kitchen stuff}, fat collected from pots and pans. --Donne. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Kitchen \Kitch"en\, v. t. To furnish food to; to entertain with the fare of the kitchen. [Obs.] --Shak. [1913 Webster]
kitchen n : a room equipped for preparing meals
